abstract.p: Thinks it would be a good idea to give writing machine to Carl Semper.

div.p: Very many thanks about Sleepers just received— The great thing is fresh Families. I have a Malvaceous plant, but not genus Gossypium so this wd be valuable fact if it sleeps— Do not waste time abtQQQQ more Leguminosæ unless you see something remarkable & new—

I do not see that any one (except you occasionally) uses the machine. It is an ugly object in the Smoking Room & I shd. think it a very good thing for me to send it as a present to Sachs You decide.— I am sure that I shall never endure to have my M.S. copied— Horace does not object to its being given.— All this is written under a mistake— I thought it was Sachs & I see it is Semper— Nevertheless I shd not at all object to give it to Semper— If you decide so, (I do not care an atom about it) it ought to be cleaned & despatched & packed by makers

div.note: The date is established by the relationship between this letter and the letters from Francis Darwin, [before 14 July 1878], and to Francis Darwin, 17 July [1878] (see n. 3, below).
See letter from Francis Darwin, [before 14 July 1878]. Malvaceae is the family of mallows; Gossypium is the genus of cotton in the family Malvaceae.

Francis had mentioned that Carl Gottfried Semper wanted to buy a typewriter like the one CD owned (letter from Francis Darwin, [before 14 July 1878]). By the time CD wrote to Francis Darwin on 17 July [1878], he had no confusion over who the typrwriter was for and made it clear that he had already suggested that his own typewriter should be sent to Semper as a gift. Horace Darwin had been so enthusiastic about the typewriter when it was first purchased that he considered getting one for himself (letter from Horace Darwin to George Howard Darwin, 1 May 1876 (DAR 258: 860)).
